intro: Malvastrum dissectum var. cockerellii, commonly known as the Desert Mallow, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its hairy, lobed leaves and showy, pink to lavender-colored flowers that bloom in summer. The plant has a sprawling growth habit and produces capsules that contain numerous small, dry seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to hot, dry environments. Its botanical features make it a distinctive and resilient species within the Malvaceae family.
